instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to predict leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops?
Output:
In the related study, two types of spectra were used: 
1. Visible spectrum and nir spectrum collected on the ground in the crop field using a field portable spectroradiometer. The spectral range of these measurements was 400-2500 nm.
2. Spectra collected from an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) using an imaging spectrometer.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict leaf N of wheat crop?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to predict leaf N of wheat crop were extreme learning machine (ELM), least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO), and support vector machine regression (SVM).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of different methods to predict leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of different methods in predict leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops was the R2 value.

instruction: What are the different regression methods used in the related study to predict leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops using spectroscopy data collected from ground-based spectroradiometer and UAV-based imaging spectrometer?
Output: The different regression methods used in the related study to predict leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops using spectroscopy data collected from a ground-based spectroradiometer and UAV-based imaging spectrometer are extreme learning machine (ELM), least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO), and support vector machine regression (SVM regression).

instruction: Can the spectroscopic method using data collected from a UAV-based imaging spectrometer be considered superior to the traditional method of using field spectral data in predicting leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops?
Output: Yes, the spectroscopic method using data collected from a UAV-based imaging spectrometer can be considered superior to the traditional method of using field spectral data in predicting leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops. The related study mentioned in the text found that the image data set acquired from the UAV gave higher performance compared to the field spectral data. The extreme learning machine (ELM) method, which was used in the related study, outperformed other methods with a maximum calibration and validation R2 of 0.99 and 0.96, respectively. This suggests that the spectroscopic method using data from a UAV-based imaging spectrometer is more accurate and reliable in predicting leaf nitrogen levels in wheat crops compared to the traditional method.
